docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 1 INITIATING PROCESS IN CIVIL PROCEEDINGS [ss 13–21]

heading.title: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS ACT 1992 (CTH)
PART 2 SERVICE OF PROCESS IN CIVIL AND CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS [ss 13–27]
DIVISION 1 INITIATING PROCESS IN CIVIL PROCEEDINGS [ss 13–21]

leg:info.leg:officialname: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS ACT 1992 (CTH)

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 2 SERVICE OF PROCESS IN CIVIL AND CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS [ss 13–27]

leg:heading.title: SERVICE OF PROCESS IN CIVIL AND CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS [ss 13–27]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 INITIATING PROCESS IN CIVIL PROCEEDINGS [ss 13–21]

p.text: This Division applies to civil proceedings in a court.
A reference in this Division to an appearance includes a reference to a notice in writing:
that a person served with an initiating process gives to the court of issue; and
that contains a statement that the person:
acknowledges service of the process; or
intends to make a submission regarding an issue arising in the proceeding in relation to which the process has been issued; or
intends to contest the court's jurisdiction to hear the proceeding; and
that:
complies with any requirements with which the notice must comply under a law of the place of issue (including rules governing the procedure of the court); or
the court determines to be acceptable despite any non-compliance with such requirements.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,110] s 15 Initiating process may be served in any part of Australia

leg:heading.title: Initiating process may be served in any part of Australia

p.text: An initiating process issued in a State may be served in another State.
Service on an individual must be effected in the same way as service of such an initiating process in the place of issue.
Service on a company or a registered body must be effected in accordance with section 9 .
Service on any other body corporate must be effected in accordance with section 10 .

Service on a body politic (for example, the Commonwealth or a State) must be effected in the same way in which process of the Supreme Court of the State in which service is to be effected may be served on the body politic.
Legislation cited in [415,110.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 s 3(1).
See the definition in s 3(1) and notes thereto.

There is no requirement for prior leave, no requirement that there be any connection between the cause of action and the State, and no requirement of a particular endorsement on the initiating process: Kontis v Barlin (1993) 115 ACTR 11 .
Service is effective only if copies of such notices as are prescribed are attached to the process, or the copy of the process, served.
Legislation cited in [415,115.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Regulations 1993 reg 4(1)(a), Form 1.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 s 16.

The prescribed notices are dealt with in reg 4(1)(a) and Form 1 of the Service and Execution of Process Regulations at [420,015] and [420,050] respectively. Under the 1901 Act there was a requirement that the process to be served be indorsed in a particular manner. It was held that a failure to comply with this requirement was an irregularity that could be waived (Lindgran v Lindgran [1956] VLR 215; [1956] ALR 731 ; Keevers v O’Neill [1977] 1 NSWLR 587; (1977) 30 FLR 300 ), and that a default judgment obtained on a technically defective originating process was not a nullity: Atlas Co of Engineers v York (1903) 29 VLR 92; 9 ALR 183 . Notwithstanding the apparently mandatory nature of the words "only if" in s 16 , a party may waive such a requirement by appearing in the court of issue and arguing the substance of an application: Roladuct Spiral Tubing Pty Ltd v C & P Trading Pty Ltd [1994] 2 Qd R 247; (1993) 114 FLR 392 .
If the person served is required or permitted to enter an appearance under a law of the place of issue, the period after service within which the person may enter an appearance is:
whichever is the longer of the following periods:
21 days;
the period in which the apppearance would have been required or permitted to be entered if the process had been served in the place of issue; or
such shorter period as the court of issue, on application, allows.
[subs (1) am Act 34 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 14]

If, under a provision (the State provision ) of the law of the place of issue, the period in which an appearance is required or permitted to be entered in respect of process served in the place of issue varies according to the distance of the place of service from another place, the period referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(ii) is to be calculated by reference to the longest distance mentioned in the State provision.
[subs (1A) insrt Act 34 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 14]
The matters that the court must take into account in determining an application to allow a shorter period include:
urgency; and
the places of residence or business of the parties; and
whether a related or similar proceeding has been commenced against the person or another person.
Legislation cited in [415,120.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 7 r 5(1), Pt 7 r 5(2).
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 s 17.

The time limited for appearance in proceedings in the Supreme Court is set out in Pt 7 r 5(1) of the Supreme Court Rules. Those times will apply subject to any contrary order made under s 17 : see Pt 7 r 5(2) .
Legislation cited in [415,120.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Acts Interpretation Act 1901 s 36.

Under the equivalent section of the 1901 Act (s 8) , specifying insufficient time for the entry of an appearance was held to be an irregularity which did not deprive the court of jurisdiction: Cadd & Co Ltd v Ludsei (1908) 10 WALR 27 . Similarly, specifying a greater time for appearance did not affect the validity of service: Pringle v Musgrove (1903) 20 WN (NSW) 280 . The day when service is effected is not counted: Acts Interpretation Act 1901 (Cth) s 36 ; McColl v Peacock [1924] VLR 102; (1924) 30 ALR 45 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,125] s 18 Appearance to state address for service

leg:heading.title: Appearance to state address for service

p.text: An appearance entered after service of the initiating process must state an address within Australia as an address for service.
The appearance is effective only if it contains an address for service.

The court of issue must set aside the appearance if, on application by the party by whom or on whose behalf the process was served, the court is satisfied that the address for service contained in the appearance is false or misleading.
Subsection (3) does not limit the court's power to set aside an appearance.

For the purposes of this Act, if the appearance would not have been required to contain an address for service had the initiating process been served in the same State as the State of the court of issue:
the appearance is taken to contain an address for service if it states an address of the person entering the appearance; and
that address is taken to be the address for service.
The court may, on application by the person served, order that:
the party by whom or on whose behalf the process was served give such security as the court specifies for the first-mentioned person's costs of and incidental to the proceeding; and
the proceeding be stayed until the security is given.
Subsection (1) does not limit the court's power to make an order requiring security for costs.

The court has a discretion whether or not to order security for costs (Sims v Robertson (1921) 38 WN (NSW) 36 ) and security will not be ordered as of course: Ramsay v Eager (1902) 27 VLR 603; 8 ALR 44 ; Conrad v Muston (1903) 20 WN (NSW) 28 . The court will consider whether the plaintiff has chosen an appropriate forum and his or her financial position: Sims v Robertson , above. Neither the bankruptcy of the plaintiff (Evans v Sneddon (1902) 28 VLR 396; 8 ALR 215 ), nor his or her poverty (White v Hardwick (1922) 23 SR (NSW) 6; 39 WN (NSW) 249 ) nor the fact that he or she has no assets (Hunting v Bear [1939] QWN 19 ; Evans v Sneddon , above) is of itself a sufficient ground for ordering that he or she give security. But where the plaintiff has chosen an inappropriate forum, security may be ordered (Paull v Pettitt (1912) 29 WN (NSW) 44 ; Watson v Jacobson (1946) 63 WN (NSW) 145 ), even where the plaintiff is financially incapable of giving security: Orr v Isles [1963] NSWR 616 . If the plaintiff has legal aid, an order for security will be refused: Orr v Isles , above. An impecunious plaintiff whose former proceedings on the same cause of action in another jurisdiction have been stayed for non-compliance with an order for security, may be ordered to give security: Badge v Oldmeadow (1911) 13 WALR 85 .
This section does not apply in relation to a proceeding in which the Supreme Court of a State is the court of issue.
The person served may apply to the court of issue for an order staying the proceeding.

The court may order that the proceeding be stayed if it is satisfied that a court of another State that has jurisdiction to determine all the matters in issue between the parties is the appropriate court to determine those matters.
The matters that the court is to take into account in determining whether that court of another State is the appropriate court for the proceeding include:
the places of residence of the parties and of the witnesses likely to be called in the proceeding; and
the place where the subject matter of the proceeding is situated; and
the financial circumstances of the parties, so far as the court is aware of them; and
any agreement between the parties about the court or place in which the proceeding should be instituted; and
the law that would be most appropriate to apply in the proceeding; and
whether a related or similar proceeding has been commenced against the person served or another person;
but do not include the fact that the proceeding was commenced in the place of issue.
The court's order may be made subject to such conditions as the court considers just and appropriate in order to facilitate determination of the matter in issue without delay or undue expense.
The court may determine the application for an order without a hearing unless the applicant or a party objects.
For the purposes of determining the application, the court may hold a hearing by audio link or audiovisual link.
[subs (7) am Act 77 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 2[3], effective 7 September 2009]
A person who is entitled to practise as a barrister, solicitor or both before a court in:
the place of issue; or
another State in which a person is participating in the hearing by audio link or audiovisual link;
has a right of audience before the court at the hearing.
[subs (8) am Act 77 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 2[4], effective 7 September 2009]
This section does not affect the court's power to stay a proceeding on a ground other than the ground mentioned in subsection (3) .
This section does not affect the operation of:
the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987; or
a corresponding law of a State.

A stay application may be made under the present section irrespective of whether or not the defendant has filed an appearance. The section does not apply to proceedings in a Supreme Court, presumably because it was intended that the cross-vesting legislation would govern the transfer of proceedings between the Supreme Courts of the states. Although there is no express provision in either this Act or the cross-vesting legislation to oust the common law principles governing a stay of proceedings on the basis of forum non conveniens (McEntee v Connor (1994) 4 Tas R 18), no doubt the practical position would be that, if a court thought that those principles were otherwise applicable, the transfer powers under the cross-vesting legislation would be enlivened: Kontis v Barlin (1993) 115 ACTR 11 .
Legislation cited in [415,135.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 s 20(4), s 20.

A stay applicant bears the onus of satisfying the court of issue that a court of another state is “the appropriate court” and that proceedings should be stayed: Rick Cobby Pty Ltd v Podesta Transport Pty Ltd (1997) 139 FLR 54 at 58; BC9702339 (clear and compelling case required); St George Bank Ltd v McTaggart [2003] 2 Qd R 568 at 574; [2003] QCA 59; BC200300414 . The criterion that the court of another state is “the appropriate court” differs from the criteria that enlivened the transfer power in the 1987 Cross Vesting legislation (“more appropriate” and “otherwise in the interests of justice”). That contrast, and the unconfined criteria relevant to the exercise of the s 20 power, has provoked judicial exegesis querying whether “the appropriate court” criterion is synonymous with the expression “more appropriate”: St George Bank Ltd v McTaggart [2003] 2 Qd R 568 at 572; [2003] QCA 59; BC200300414 .

Determining the appropriate court certainly requires identification of the issues in the proceedings (St George Bank Ltd v McTaggart [2003] 2 Qd R 568 at 572 and 575; [2003] QCA 59; BC200300414 ) but, as the criteria specified in s 20(4) indicate, also requires an assessment of the materiality of those issues to the circumstances of the witnesses and the parties. In some cases, the s 20(4) discretion has been described as requiring identification of the court with which the proceedings have the most real and substantial connection, and which court is the “most natural” forum: St George Bank Ltd v McTaggart [2003] 2 Qd R 568; [2003] QCA 59; BC200300414 citing Valkama v Jamieson (1994) 11 SR (WA) 246 at 250 . This exegesis may be appropriate as one way of summarising the relevant criteria and expressing the determinative consideration in particular circumstances. But some care should be taken to focus attention primarily on the actual and unqualified expression in s 20(4) , “the appropriate court”. The mandated criteria do not preclude issues of convenience, cost or comparative hardship from influencing either the assessment of whether another court is the appropriate forum, or the exercise of the stay discretion after that satisfaction has been reached.

The existence, in an agreement between the parties, of a jurisdiction clause in favour of the forum in which it is sought to stay proceedings will not be fatal to an application to stay the proceedings: Rick Manietta Pty Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (VSC, McDonald J, 8 September 1995, unreported, BC9503951) .

If an initiating process has been served under this Division, a court of a State that is not the place of issue must not restrain a party in the proceeding from taking a step in the proceeding on the ground that the place of issue is not the appropriate forum for the proceeding.
